title: William Macbride Childs
text:
William Macbride Childs (1869–1939) was an <a href="England">English</a> academic administrator and historian, who was involved in the foundation of the <a href="University%20of%20Reading">University of Reading</a> and who served briefly as its first <a href="Chancellor%20%28education%29">vice-chancellor</a>.
Biography.
Childs was born, on 3 January 1869, in the village of <a href="Carrington%2C%20Lincolnshire">Carrington</a>, situated some north of <a href="Boston%2C%20Lincolnshire">Boston</a> in <a href="Lincolnshire">Lincolnshire</a>. He was the son of the Revd William Linington Childs, vicar of Carrington, and his second wife, Henrietta Fowles Bell. He had no brothers or sisters, but had a half-brother and two half-sisters by his father's first marriage. He attended <a href="Portsmouth%20Grammar%20School">Portsmouth Grammar School</a> and graduated from <a href="Keble%20College%2C%20Oxford">Keble College</a> of the <a href="University%20of%20Oxford">University of Oxford</a> in 1891.
In 1892 Childs served briefly as a secretary to <a href="Sir%20Arthur%20Dyke%20Acland%2C%2013th%20Baronet">Sir Arthur Dyke Acland</a>, who at the time was <a href="Secretary%20of%20State%20for%20Education%20and%20Skills">Vice-President of the Committee on Education</a>, the <a href="Cabinet%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">cabinet</a> post that then supervised <a href="education%20in%20the%20United%20Kingdom">education in the United Kingdom</a>. In 1893 he became a <a href="lecturer">lecturer</a> in history at the <a href="University%20College%2C%20Reading">University College</a> in <a href="Reading%2C%20Berkshire">Reading</a>, being promoted to vice-principal in 1900.
In 1903 Childs succeeded <a href="Halford%20Mackinder">Halford Mackinder</a> as principal of the college. He made it his aim to turn the college into a University, working to this end by attracting students from a distance with hostels and, eventually, halls of residence. He also raised funds from prominent local residents, including <a href="George%20William%20Palmer%20%28England%29">George William Palmer</a> and <a href="Alfred%20Palmer%20%28businessman%29">Alfred Palmer</a>, both proprietors of <a href="Huntley%20%26amp%3B%20Palmers">Huntley & Palmers</a>, and Harriet Loyd-Lindsay, wife of <a href="Robert%20Loyd-Lindsay%2C%201st%20Baron%20Wantage">Robert, 1st Baron Wantage</a>. His first application for a charter, in 1920, was turned down, but a second application, in 1925, succeeded. In 1926, when the <a href="University%20of%20Reading">University of Reading</a> officially received that charter, Childs became the first vice-chancellor, being born aloft by his students and carried around the grounds.
Childs retired at the age of 60, in 1929. He died on 21 June 1939 at his home at <a href="Hermitage%2C%20Berkshire">Hermitage</a> in <a href="Berkshire">Berkshire</a>. Childs Hall, a hall of residence on the University of Reading's <a href="Whiteknights%20Park">Whiteknights Park</a> campus, is named in honour of William Macbride Childs.
